nodes.text: The Almost Ideal Demand System (AIDS) provides a flexible, theoretically consistent demand system that is preferable to existing models (Rotterdam, translog) for testing and extending conventional demand analysis
AIDS cost function is constructed from PIGLOG preferences: log c(u,p) = (1-u) log a(p) + u log b(p) with specific flexible functional forms for log a(p) and log b(p)
From the AIDS cost function, budget shares wi can be derived as linear functions of log prices and log real expenditure: wi = ai + sum_j yij log pj + beta_i log(x/P)
AIDS satisfies key theoretical properties when parameter restrictions hold: adding-up, homogeneity, and Slutsky symmetry are linear constraints on parameters
AIDS permits exact aggregation over heterogeneous households under PIGLOG/PIGL assumptions, yielding a representative consumer with an adjusted representative budget x/k
AIDS is a flexible functional form: it provides a first-order approximation to any demand system because parameters can be chosen to match derivatives of any true model at a point
Specification choices: log a(p) and log b(p) include linear and quadratic log-price terms so that cost function is linearly homogeneous and sufficiently parameterized for flexibility
Parameter restrictions: adding-up requires sum_i ai =1 and sum_i beta_i =0; homogeneity requires sum_j yij =0; symmetry requires yij = yji
Negativity (concavity) of the cost function cannot be guaranteed by parameter restrictions alone and must be checked using eigenvalues of the Slutsky matrix or the transformed K matrix

Household heterogeneity is accommodated via household scale factors kh allowing taste variation; omitted index k can be absorbed into intercepts if k is constant or uncorrelated with prices and mean expenditure

Estimation methods: estimate non-linear system (levels) by concentrated maximum likelihood or approximate by linearizing using Stone price index P* so each equation can be OLS estimated equation by equation

Model selection and restrictions can be imposed equation-by-equation for yij to reduce parameters; after selecting restrictions the full system should be reestimated to restore efficiency and adding-up
AIDS includes and relates to other models: it nests linear expenditure/Gorman polar forms under special cases and can be linked to a restricted indirect translog when aggregation conditions hold

Empirical application: estimating AIDS on UK annual data 1954-1974 for eight nondurable commodity groups using both levels and first differences, with P* as initial index and symmetric P after iteration

Result: Unconstrained AIDS fits budget shares well; many price parameters yij are significant; expenditure effects classify food and housing as necessities, others as luxuries; general price inelasticity observed

Result and conclusion: Homogeneity and symmetry are decisively rejected in levels; imposing homogeneity introduces positive serial correlation in residuals and symmetry estimates violate concavity, suggesting omitted dynamics or aggregation effects
